image:image.image:title: IMG_4702
image:image.image:caption: The first stage of fieldwork: getting to site. I'm lucky to do fieldwork only a half-day drive from Perth, which meant we could drive directly to site on that first day!

image:image.image:title: IMG_4735
image:image.image:caption: Of course, the course of PhD fieldwork never did run smooth, and my track record for needing to buy replacement tyres remains intact. Why is it always the expensive ones that I stake?

image:image.image:title: Baja_California_in_Mexico
image:image.image:caption: Baja California (shown in red). Image via Wikimedia Commons.

image:image.image:title: Shell mound, Awonga/Luthinh area
image:image.image:caption: Shell mound covered in vegetation, Cape York Peninsula. Image via Mick Morrison

image:image.image:title: nla.obj-147827505-1
image:image.image:caption: Gumbaloo gathering shellfish at low tide, Liverpool River, Arnhem Land, Northern Territory, 1952 Axel Poignant. Image via National Library of Australia

image:image.image:title: Shell mound from Weipa NLA
image:image.image:caption: A shell mound from Weipa, photographed in 1958. Image via National Archives of Australia.

image:image.image:title: TC lyr 5b
image:image.image:caption: A 13,000 yr old campfire bed - rich in animal bones, but not so much quokka. Image: Joe Dortch.

image:image.image:title: TC forest mist
image:image.image:caption: Karri forest around a cave site is great quokka habitat

image:image.image:title: nlapic-an7404363-1-v
image:image.image:caption: The first panel of Ensign Robert Dale's panorama of King George Sound shows an Aboriginal camp in the foreground, with fires burning in the dense vegetation that surrounds the cleared lands occupied by Europeans.

image:image.image:title: IMG_4111
image:image.image:caption: During excavation, sediment is sieved and is collected. The material being sorted here includes bones, teeth, fragments of eggshell and charcoal.

image:image.image:title: nla pic-an2962715-s20-v
image:image.image:caption: Joseph Lycett's 1817 painting shows Aboriginal men using fire to burn vegetation and flush out kangaroos

image:image.image:title: 2014044 NSCP Figure 1
image:image.image:caption: Map of the lower Mid West, showing the locations of all dated archaeological shell middens. Image source.

image:image.image:title: 2014044 NSCP Figure 1
image:image.image:caption: Map of the lower Mid West, showing the locations of all dated archaeological shell middens. Image source.

image:image.image:title: DSC00841
image:image.image:caption: Some of the shells from an eroded section of the North Head midden, including turban snails, chitons, abalone, and limpets.

image:image.image:title: DSC00839
image:image.image:caption: Some of the shells from the North Head midden, including Turban snail

image:image.image:title: DSC00904
image:image.image:caption: Looking south from North Head towards Jurien Bay. Wide, parabolic bays like this stretch between rocky headlands in the southern end of the study area.

image:image.image:title: Carly Monks 329
image:image.image:caption: The base of a glass bottle, showing breaks that are consistent with knapping. Photo: Ian McCann.

image:image.image:title: DSC01167
image:image.image:caption: Caves provide shelter to people and animals, making them ideal places to look for evidence of past activity.
